Lamp & Shade Craft Kitchen & Cocktails - BRPH Skip to content Toggle Navigation Who We Are Culture History Organization Who We Serve Aerospace Commercial Defense Education Entertainment Hospitality Manufacturing What We Do ThirdSpace‚Ñ¢ News and Now Updates Ideas & Insights On The Boards Portfolio Careers Contact Locations Subcontractor Prequalification Lamp & Shade Craft Kitchen & Cocktails Services Interior Design Cocktail Lamp, LLC Orlando, Florida Breathing new life into a landmark Orlando building, BRPH has transformed the former The Lamp & Shade Fair repair shop into the colorful and whimsical Lamp & Shade Craft Kitchen and Cocktails. This up-and-coming Central Florida hotspot pays playful homage to its 40-year roots by incorporating lamp shade motifs throughout, including a mural by a local artist depicting fashionable figures adorned with lampshades to create plenty of Instagram-able moments. The interior features a custom wallcovering by Astek, interweaving lamp shades into a dynamic squirrel pattern. The bar is the focal point of the space with integrated lighting accessorized by colorful accents and seating for 22 patrons. A collaboration with Barn Light, a Central Florida lighting manufacturer, resulted in an eclectic collection of bespoke fixtures that illuminate the cozy space. A curated collection of furniture provides 72 lounge seat options for guests to cozy up with a craft cocktail and socialize with friends. Outside, a profound diversity mural by Luna Mosaic Arts, commissioned in 2016 to honor the Pulse Nightclub victims, was thoughtfully preserved. This blend of history and creativity makes this destination a vibrant tribute to its past and a beacon of interior design ingenuity. Mills Ave. in Mills 50. Like most restaurant openings, Lamp & Shade has been plagued by delays, but the restaurant has cleared numerous hurdles and is poised to open in early December. We can now lift the shade off to reveal some details about the concept. Ryan Stewart, executive chef of Thriving Hospitality, says Lamp & Shade will offer an ‚ÄúAsian-influenced, tapas-style menu‚Äù (menu and food images posted below) as well as a ‚Äúcomprehensive beverage program‚Äù focusing on ‚Äúriffs of tiki classics‚Äù overseen by part-owner and beverage developer Courtney Williams. All of Lamp & Shade‚Äôs cocktails will be designed to pair with Stewart‚Äôs menu. The restaurant‚Äôs playful name, of course, pays homage to the longstanding lamp store that first opened in this space back in 1963. Judging from the above renderings, lighting will certainly be a central focus of the restaurant‚Äôs interior design. The mural inside the restaurant by artist Sumner Mormeneo fuses elements of surrealism, Dada and Pop Art and is intended to be a conversation piece exploring the meaning behind the concept. The restaurant‚Äôs exterior features the ‚ÄúDiversity Mural‚Äù by artist Cherie Bosela , a work memorializing the victims of the Pulse Nightclub shooting and dedicated to all who suffer from discrimination. The Thriving Hospitality group also includes Thrive Cocktail Lounge & Eatery downtown, and Bounce House Social Eats near UCF. Check out food photos as well as the food and drink menus below. (Amy Drew Thompson/Orlando Sentinel) By Amy Drew Thompson | amthompson@orlandosentinel.com | Orlando Sentinel PUBLISHED: September 5, 2024 at 5:00 AM EDT More than 10 years ago, I brought a brass globe into Lamp & Shade Fair, a decades-old, family-run store on Mills Avenue, and they turned it into a pendant fixture. Suspended from the extra-high ceiling of my entryway, it radiated welcome ‚Äî even from the street, as it was visible through a window above the home‚Äôs front door. There‚Äôs solid stuff simmering at Boiled Fish | Review The shop had old-school feels in the best way. Outside, a colorful mural welcomed shoppers. Inside, close quarters and a bit of repair-shop clutter made it cozy, comfortable ‚Äîthe same sort of vibes I get from shoe-repair shops, redolent of polish and leather and¬† craftsmanship. It spoke to a certain level of service and expertise. The ceilings at 1336 N. Mills Ave. are no longer low-slung. In fact, they soar. Those who remember Lamp & Shade Fair will find the airy new restaurant unrecognizable. Everyone will find it beautiful. (Amy Drew Thompson/Orlando Sentinel) Loads of natural light, along with clean-lined pendants, an illuminated wall behind the bar and a smattering of fixtures amid the exposed ducts and beams do their jobs well. This means that I ‚Äî and others intent on showing off the new ownership‚Äôs level of service and expertise ‚Äî can forgo those obnoxious ring lights when snapping pics of the workmanship. This is Lamp & Shade Craft Kitchen and Cocktails , Mills 50‚Äôs newest hot spot for sips and snacks and being seen, and the third Orlando offering from local restaurant group Thriving Hospitality ( Thrive Cocktail Lounge & Eatery , Bounce House ). Shades of chefdom. Left to right, Lamp & Shade Sous Chef Stephanie Roig-Hernandez, Executive Chef Ryan Stewart and R&D Chef Courtney Deneau. (Photo courtesy Thriving Hospitality) ‚ÄúThis one is a departure from both,‚Äù says Ryan Stewart, executive chef for Thriving Hospitality, which acquired the building before the pandemic. ‚ÄúIt took us close to three years before it was all said and done.‚Äù Not surprising. The 50-year-old building, a retail operation, was hardly fit for restauranting. Everything here is either retrofitted or new. Murals inside playfully honor the venue‚Äôs past, as does the name. Smoked trout dip is served with house-made chips that are cooked to order. (Amy Drew Thompson/Orlando Sentinel) ‚ÄúMills 50 is very vibrant. It‚Äôs the spot to be,‚Äù says Stewart, a Nashville native whose Orlando tenure began 10 years ago at Universal CityWalk‚Äôs Cowfish. ‚ÄúThis building was so important for so long in the community ‚Äî we asked the previous owners if we could keep the name. They thought we were crazy, but they were honored.‚Äù It‚Äôs doubtful any lighting store was ever such a scene. The rum- and pisco-based Pink + White is a super-refresher that showcases that POW dragonfruit hue. (Amy Drew Thompson/Orlando Sentinel) Lamp & Shade cattily urges you to ‚Äúthrow some shade‚Äù via the neon photo-op in the back, but the place is buzzing with friendly, if trendy, energy. Well-planned seating and those tall walls make the space feel airy, even when the bar crawlers are out in full force. The menu here suits that M.O. ‚Äî shareable small plates and playful, posh cocktails are the order ‚Äî but can easily handle a group hang or extended dinner if you have plans to linger. Cases in point: larger ‚Äúfor the table‚Äù dishes, including shiitake risotto and a bone-in tomahawk steak. Either way, the joint is fashionable. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre blessed to have the vibes,‚Äù says Stewart. ‚ÄúFor lack of a better term, it‚Äôs the ‚Äògrown and sexy‚Äô coming out at Lamp. They‚Äôll go to The Guesthouse or Sunroom across the street, pop over here for a drink and some plates and when we see them leave, a lot are headed down Mills for a nightcap or to enjoy the next part of their evening.‚Äù The Strand is now doing business as d.b.a. in the chic, chill space next door | Review The location is a hospitality hotbed. ‚ÄúOn almost any given night, I will recognize a chef or bar staffer from another restaurant. I‚Äôm always telling my team there‚Äôs a ton of eyes on us. The food has to be perfect. The drinks have to be perfect.‚Äù Taste is subjective, of course, but if all you ate with were your eyes, you‚Äôd leave fat and happy. Shiitalkin' Shade is a Ketel One-Sh≈çch≈´ amalgam with fruity Mandarin punch. Shiitake syrup gives it a lingering earthy undertone that we loved, but probably isn't for everyone. (Amy Drew Thompson/Orlando Sentinel) Here, gorgeous cocktails move from bar to tables like a runway show, a parade of color and and glassware and garnish. Take the brunchy delights of the Pink & White ($13), a rum and pisco refresher with its dragonfruit drama and dehydrated fascinator amid flawless ice or the Shiitalkin‚Äô Shade ($14), a bright, citrusy offering with the unique add of shiitake syrup. Not for everyone, but we loved its lingering earthiness. Plates, too, dazzle. For fans of the fried stuff, crispy tofu bites with spicy chimichurri aioli are a fun choice.(Amy Drew Thompson/Orlando Sentinel) On a first visit, the crispy tofu ($12) was a hearty winner, served in a martini glass with chimichurri aioli and addictively spicy lotus chips. It‚Äôs one of many vegan offerings here (and done in its own dedicated fryer). This is something Stewart and his team spent time on. There are eight to 10 vegan dishes on the menu here. None are throwaway plant-based box checkers. The brunch menu‚Äôs plantain pancakes, in fact, are sublime. My leftovers were destroyed by two discriminating teenagers before they made it into the fridge. ‚ÄúWe wanted the vegan community to be able to come in and enjoy a full meal sitting beside their [non-vegan] friends, to eat and be full and leave ecstatic.‚Äù Behold the plantain pancakes.  You want these whether you're vegan or just love pancakes. Fluffy and hearty and crunchy and coconut-creamy, all at once. (Amy Drew Thompson/Orlando Sentinel) The pancakes ($16), fluffy but weighted with the caramelized starchiness of plantain bits, come layered with cinnamon sugar and corn flake crumble, a pouf of coconut whipped cream alongside. And while we‚Äôre talking brunch, the king crab and grits ($36) isn‚Äôt just a must-get flavor bomb; it‚Äôs a must-share for its richness and an exemplary representation of Stewart‚Äôs Asian-influenced menu. Here, Creole meets Korea in a sauce built on kimchi and charred tomatoes. Super delish king crab 'n' grits. It's a pricier brunch plate at $36, but hearty as hell, shareable and decadent. Calorie counters, steer way clear. (Amy Drew Thompson/Orlando Sentinel) ‚ÄúI‚Äôm from the South,‚Äù Stewart laughs, ‚Äúso butter makes the grits for me ‚Ä¶ that amazing base, with Applewood-smoked bacon, lots of butter and love and all that king crab, we‚Äôre getting it out of the shells and chopping it up and putting a nice portion in the center with fresh chives.‚Äù Get it. Our enthusiastic server sold us on the Curry Green Mussels, which are something of a love letter. Chef Ryan Stewart made them for his wife. Not surprising that some guests order a side of the soppable sauce. You might find yourself spooning it up when the bivalves have gone bye-bye. (Amy Drew Thompson/Orlando Sentinel) There are other seafood love stories on this menu, too. On our first visit, the server‚Äôs exuberance for the curry mussels ($18) sold us. Some customers, Stewart tells me, order a side of the sauce to go. I‚Äôm not surprised. Our server brought us spoons for the occasion to sample the creamy sweetness and subtle heat on its own. We resisted extra bread, as there was much to taste, but it‚Äôs something you might want to ask for upfront. Duck dumplings ($14), crisp purses loaded with ginger and garlic flavor, were a hit, though I‚Äôd have passed on the orange aioli accompaniment in which they sat. My companion, however, loved the stuff. Menu writing is tricky. Duck dumplings atop orange aioli. (Amy Drew Thompson/Orlando Sentinel) ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre at a juncture here,‚Äù says Stewart. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre close to Winter Park, with a crowd that wants its food a certain way. You have the industry people who want their food a certain way. You have the Mills community with its own preferences. It‚Äôs been a big eye-opener for me. I‚Äôve never had this much feedback on my food before.‚Äù As with any art form, you can‚Äôt please everybody. ‚ÄúMore than anything, though, it‚Äôs made me a better chef.‚Äù The Shady Spice is a mellow brunch-menu cocktail, with notes of gingerbread and tea. (Amy Drew Thompson/Orlando Sentinel) Smoked trout dip with radish and leek, shallot and bonito flakes, is dreamy alongside housemade chips that are fried to order ($24). The Shady Spice cocktail ($14) feels like fall in a glass, tea meets gingerbread. It came recommended by a local chef I know who spotted me from his perch at the bar. Stewart‚Äôs not fibbing when he says the restaurant crowd has made Lamp & Shade a new habit since doors opened back in May. It makes sense. It‚Äôs not just well-located. It‚Äôs lit.
